title: Sattriya
short_description: Originally performed in monasteries, this form is a way to celebrate the spiritual beliefs of Vaishnavism.
long_description:
Sattriya is a classical dance-drama form from Assam, introduced in the 15th century by the great Vaishnava saint Srimanta Sankardev as a powerful medium for propagating the Vaishnava faith. For centuries, it was nurtured and preserved within the 'Sattras' (monasteries) by male monks (Bhokots).

In the modern era, it has moved from the monastery to the metropolitan stage and is now performed by women as well. The dance is devotional in nature, describing the deeds of Krishna and Rama.
costume_and_makeup: Assamese Pat Silk costumes (Muga). Men wear dhotis and turbans; women wear traditional Assamese mekhela chador.
key_traditions: Performed as part of prayer services

top_places.title: Majuli Island
top_places.summary: The world's largest river island and hub of Sattriya culture. Visit the Sattras (monasteries).

practical_info.audience_tips: Respect the sanctity of the Sattra.
